subject: Home & DIY
title: The Indus Valley Had Toilets in 2500 BC
description: A quick, practical guide to The Indus Valley Had Toilets in 2500 BC.

hook.text: Mohenjo-daro had flush toilets and covered sewers 4,500 years ago. Most medieval European cities had neither.

buildup.text: Each Indus Valley home had a private bathroom with brick-lined drains connected to a citywide sewer system.

discovery.text: Wastewater flowed through covered street channels, with inspection manholes at regular intervals for upkeep.

twist.text: This system collapsed when the civilization declined around 1900 BC. Humanity wouldn't match it for 3,000 years.

climax.text: Indus sanitation was so advanced that archaeologists initially assumed the ruins were much more recent.

punchline.text: Indoor plumbing: invented, lost, reinvented millennia later.

quiz.question: What remarkable feature did homes in Mohenjo-daro have 4,500 years ago?
options: Private bathrooms with drains connected to a city sewer system
Hot and cold running water from a central boiler
Glass pipes that carried water from mountain springs
